user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarLock_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarLock_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&impl->mut);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CondVarLock_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment declares a non-pointer array of mutable records: OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[...]. The pointer used in the function (impl) must be a non-const pointer because pthread_mutex_lock expects a mutable pthread_mutex_t within the record, so const-qualification is not appropriate. A rule violation would occur if a pointer were left non-const even though the pointed-to object is never modified (e.g. returning a non-const pointer to truly read-only data), but that is not the case here.
